facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 1131 of 1974 by Special Leave from the Judgment Order dated 5th February 1974 of the Madras High Court in W. Appeal No. 67/1974.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1131 of 1974 Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment Order dated 5th February, 1974 of the Madras High Court in W. Appeal No. 67/1974.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by ALAGIRISWAMI, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by ALAGIRISWAMI, J. The appellant entered service as a Junior Engineer in the Highways Department of the then Province of Madras on 21-8-1946.

facts.text: Appellant entered service as a Junior Engineer in the Highways Department of the then Province of Madras on 21-8-1946.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant entered service as a Junior Engineer in the Highways Department of the then Province of Madras on 21-8-1946. He was promoted as an Assistant Engineer on 12-3-1951.

facts.text: Appellant was promoted as an Assistant Engineer on 12-3-1951.

anchor.surface_text: He was promoted as an Assistant Engineer on 12-3-1951. In 1955 he was selected by the State Public Service Commission as an Assistant Engineer along with respondents 2 to 4 and was Placed above them in rank.

facts.text: In 1955 appellant was selected by the State Public Service Commission as an Assistant Engineer along with respondents 2 to 4 and was placed above them in rank.

anchor.surface_text: In 1955 he was selected by the State Public Service Commission as an Assistant Engineer along with respondents 2 to 4 and was Placed above them in rank. In 1957 the 2nd respondent was promoted as Divisional Engineer.

facts.text: In 1957 the 2nd respondent was promoted as Divisional Engineer.

anchor.surface_text: In 1957 the 2nd respondent was promoted as Divisional Engineer. Thereupon the appellant made a representation to the Government. He made another representation in the same year.

facts.text: Appellant made a representation to the Government in 1957 after 2nd respondent's promotion.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant made a representation to the Government. He made another representation in the same year. He made two further representations in the year 1968 to companysider his case for promotion as Superintending Engineer along with his juniors.

facts.text: Appellant made another representation to the Government in 1957.

anchor.surface_text: He made another representation in the same year. He made two further representations in the year 1968 to companysider his case for promotion as Superintending Engineer along with his juniors.

facts.text: Appellant made two further representations in 1968 to consider his case for promotion as Superintending Engineer along with his juniors.

anchor.surface_text: He made two further representations in the year 1968 to companysider his case for promotion as Superintending Engineer along with his juniors. Respondents 2 to 4 were again promoted as Superintending Engineers over the head of the appellant.

facts.text: Respondents 2 to 4 were promoted as Superintending Engineers over the head of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents 2 to 4 were again promoted as Superintending Engineers over the head of the appellant. In 1970 the 5th respondent who was junior to the appellant as Assistant Engineer and Divisional Engineer was promoted Superintending Engineer over the head of the appellant.

facts.text: In 1970 the 5th respondent, who was junior to the appellant as Assistant Engineer and Divisional Engineer, was promoted as Superintending Engineer over the head of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In 1970 the 5th respondent who was junior to the appellant as Assistant Engineer and Divisional Engineer was promoted Superintending Engineer over the head of the appellant. The appellant himself was promoted as Superintending Engineer on 23-1-1971, He, therefore, filed a writ petition before the High Court of Madras.

facts.text: Appellant was promoted as Superintending Engineer on 23-1-1971.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant himself was promoted as Superintending Engineer on 23-1-1971, He, therefore, filed a writ petition before the High Court of Madras. That petition was dismissed as also the appeal against the dismissal.

facts.text: Appellant filed a writ petition before the High Court of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: He, therefore, filed a writ petition before the High Court of Madras. That petition was dismissed as also the appeal against the dismissal. The main grievance of the appellant is that the 2nd respondent who was junior to him as Assistant Engineer was promoted as Divisional Engineer in 1957 by relaxing the relevant rules regarding the length of service necessary for promotion as Divisional Engineer and that his claim for a similar relaxation was number companysidered at that time.

facts.text: Writ petition before Madras High Court was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: That petition was dismissed as also the appeal against the dismissal. The main grievance of the appellant is that the 2nd respondent who was junior to him as Assistant Engineer was promoted as Divisional Engineer in 1957 by relaxing the relevant rules regarding the length of service necessary for promotion as Divisional Engineer and that his claim for a similar relaxation was number companysidered at that time.

facts.text: Appeal against writ dismissal was dismissed by Madras High Court.

anchor.surface_text: That petition was dismissed as also the appeal against the dismissal.

facts.text: Main grievance of appellant: 2nd respondent, junior as AE, promoted DE in 1957 by relaxing rules on service length, appellant's claim for similar relaxation not considered.

anchor.surface_text: The main grievance of the appellant is that the 2nd respondent who was junior to him as Assistant Engineer was promoted as Divisional Engineer in 1957 by relaxing the relevant rules regarding the length of service necessary for promotion as Divisional Engineer and that his claim for a similar relaxation was number companysidered at that time.

facts.text: Madras High Court judge viewed relaxation for 2nd respondent without considering appellant's case as arbitrary.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge of the Madras High Court who heard the writ petition was of the view that the relaxation of the rules in favour of the 2nd respondent without companysidering the appellants case was arbitrary. In view of the statement on behalf of the Government that such relaxation was given only in the case of overseas scholars, which statement was number companytroverted, it is number possible to agree with the view of the learned Judge,.

facts.text: Government stated relaxation given only to overseas scholars, not controverted.

facts.text: Respondents 3 and 4 promoted as Divisional Engineers over appellant's head.

facts.text: Court holds appellant should have approached within 6 months to a year of promotions.

anchor.surface_text: A person aggrieved by an order of promoting a junior over his bead should approach the Court at least within six months or at the most a year of such promotion.

facts.text: Writ petition should have been dismissed in limine due to delay.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners petition should, therefore have been dismissed in limine. Entertaining such petitions is a waste of time of the companyrt.
